content: Singaporean politician **Mak Pak Shee** ([Chinese](/wiki/Chinese_language): 麦柏士; [pinyin](/wiki/Pinyin): *Mài Bǎishì*) was a Singaporean politician. ## Career An [African Chinese](/wiki/African_Chinese) with [Cantonese](/wiki/Cantonese_people) ancestry, Mak was the leader of the Singapore-based [Labour Party](/wiki/Labour_Front). He left the party in August 1950. When he was in the [Cabinet](/wiki/Cabinet_of_Singapore), he held the position of Junior Minister. In his book *One Man's View of the World* (2013), Singapore's first [Prime Minister](/wiki/Prime_Minister_of_Singapore) [Lee Kuan Yew](/wiki/Lee_Kuan_Yew) described Mak as a "fixer – somebody who facilitated the fulfilment of favours for a fee". ## Lawsuits In July 1948, Mak was meted a fine of S$250 for inappropriately including the honorifics "MB, BS" in his name. ## Personal life Mak had eight sons. His third son, Mak Kok Hoe, died aged eight in February 1957 and was buried at [Bidadari Cemetery](/wiki/Bidadari_Cemetery). This article about a politician from Singapore is a stub. You can help Wikipedia by expanding it. - v - t - e
title: Mak Pak Shee
